INCREASED PENALTIES FOR CHILD SEX TRAFFICKING AND CHILD PROSTITUTION OFFENSES. Increased penalties for child sex trafficking and child prostitution offenses under title 18, United States Code, include raising minimum sentences to 30 years for coercion, 15 years for transportation of minors, and 10 years for other related offenses. The amendment modifies subsections (a) and (b) by specifying minimum prison terms of 10 years or life for certain offenses. SEC. 5. SEX TOURISM AND REMOVAL OF SEX OFFENDERS. The Attorney General must notify the Secretary of State and the Secretary of Homeland Security about convictions related to sex offenses. The Secretary of State can refuse to issue a passport to individuals convicted of certain offenses and may also revoke or restrict passports in such cases. The Secretary of Homeland Security must place aliens convicted of sex offenses in removal proceedings. Section 212(a)(2) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include sexual abuse of a minor as a ground for inadmissibility. An alien convicted of a sex offense, as defined in the Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006, will be considered to have committed sexual abuse of a minor and will be ineligible for any discretionary relief under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Protection and Safety Act of 2006 defines a sex offense as sexual abuse of a minor.
